pages.title: Hopper
pages.text: By placing a line of $(item)Hoppers$() all pointing into each other, items can be transported in all directions except up. $(br2)On large scale, $(item)Hoppers$() have been known to create lag.

pages.title: Water streams
pages.text: A less iron expensive method is the use of $(item)Water$() streams. This uses the mechanic of dropped items moving in flowing water streams. $(br2)Since $(item)Water$() can only flow 7 blocks from the source, it is usually necessary to use multiple sources. To handle the breaks, a $(item)Packed Ice$() block and $(item)Sign$() can be used. When the items come out of one stream, they will slide across the ice to the next.
Water flowing on $(item)Packed Ice$() or $(item)Blue Ice$() makes the items go faster, reducing the delay.

pages.title: Water elevators
pages.text: When a $(item)Water$() $(n)source$() is directly above a $(item)Magma Block$(), a whirlpool bubble column is created, going downward from the highest source block. $(br)Anything encountering the bubble column is pulled down, including items, $(item)Boats$(), $(thing)Players$() and mobs. $(br2)And $(item)Soulsand$() do the same thing upwards.

pages.title: Rails
pages.text: Items can also be transported on $(item)Rails$(), they can be transferred into and out of $(item)Minecart with a Chest$() using $(item)Hoppers$().

pages.title: Dropper
pages.text: $(item)Dropper$() transportation usually work by having a line of them pointing into each other. $(br2)When the $(item)Droppers$() are powered, items can travel to the next $(item)Dropper$(). $(br2)This works in all directions.
This design is a self powering item elevator.
